metadata.case_name: Shyamal Chakraborty v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Detenu detained by order No. 3846-D.D.S dated 13th November, 1968 passed by the Commissioner of Police, Calcutta under section 3(2) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.
Detenu arrested on November 13, 1968 and served with grounds of detention in English and vernacular on the same day.
Commissioner of Police reported detention to State Government on 15th November, 1968 with grounds and particulars.
Governor approved detention order on 19th November, 1968 under section 3(3) and reported to Central Government under section 3(4).
Detenu's case placed before Advisory Board on 7th December, 1968 under section 9.
Advisory Board opined on 6th January, 1969 that there was sufficient cause for detention.
No representation submitted by detenu to State Government before Advisory Board opinion.
Governor confirmed detention order on 8th January, 1969.
Detenu made representations on 13th January, 1969 and 16th January, 1969.
Representations sent to Commissioner of Police for report; on 1st April, 1969, he informed no recommendation for release.
Representation dated 13th January, 1969 sent back later; 16th January representation untraceable but similar.
Supreme Court issued notice on 28th March, 1969 to show cause why rule nisi not issued.

Ground 1: On 28-6-68 at about 6 pm, detenu with associates armed with lathis, iron rods, acid bulbs etc. committed riot in Kumartuli Park, severely assaulted Shri Amal Krishna Roy, indiscriminately used weapons endangering human lives.

Ground 2: On 23-7-68 at about 6.10 p.m., detenu with associates armed with lathis, iron rod, hockey sticks etc. attacked constables Sankar Lal Bose and Jagdish Singh on Kaliprosad Chakraborty Street near Gaudiya Math, preventing discharge of duties; constable Bose sustained bleeding injuries.

Ground 3: In night of 3-10-68 between 11.50 p.m. and 1.30 a.m., detenu with associates armed with deadly weapons took part in riot at Rabindra Sarani from Bug Bazar to Kumartuli Street, hurled bombs, brickbats, soda water bottles indiscriminately endangering human lives.

In representation dated 13th January, 1969, detenu stated grounds false, he is poor man with miserable family conditions, living peacefully, never committed acts prejudicial to public order or communal harmony; prayed to be produced before Advisory Board and released.

legal_issues.text: Whether the detenu's representation was considered by the Government.
Whether grounds mentioning offences under Indian Penal Code can be used for detention except in emergencies.
Whether the grounds have any relation to the maintenance of public order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Detenu's representation was not considered by the Government.
Grounds furnished mention offences under Indian Penal Code and cannot be used for detaining except in emergencies.
Grounds do not have any relation to maintenance of public order.

respondent_arguments.text: Representations were sent for report and process was underway; no breach as no representation before Advisory Board and Court notice intervened.
Grounds relate to public order as detenu acted with associates armed with weapons, committing riots endangering locality and preventing police duties.

court_reasoning.text: No breach of provisions regarding representation: detenu made none before Advisory Board; Government in process when Court notice issued; representation merely denied grounds and sought release/production post-Advisory Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Impossible to produce before Advisory Board after it dealt with matter.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds must relate to public order, not merely law and order; distinction between serious disorder affecting community and minor breaches.
Each ground involves detenu with armed associates committing riots, assaults endangering lives in locality, attacking police, terrorising area; affects public at large, not just individuals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object to terrorise locality and halt law and order machinery.

holdings.text: No breach of section 7 regarding consideration of representation.
Grounds of detention relate to maintenance of public order, not merely law and order.
Commissioner could conclude detenu likely to act prejudicially to public order based on grounds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pushkar Mukherjee Ors. v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between public order and law/order; serious disorder affecting community vs minor breaches.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of detention, approval, reporting, representations, Advisory Board.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences like rioting, assault mentioned in grounds.

outcome.summary: Court rejects all three grounds urged by petitioner, finds no breach in consideration of representation and holds detention grounds relate to public order; trusts State Government to deal with representations promptly.

key_quotes.text: "the grounds must have relevance to the maintenance of public order, and that they should not relate merely to the maintenance of order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Restates principle on public order vs law and order.

key_quotes.text: "in contravention of any law always affects order but before it can be said to affect public order it must affect the community or the public at large."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Ramaswami J. on test for public order.

key_quotes.text: "The object of the detenu seems to have been to terrorise the locality and bring the whole machinery of law and order to a halt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key finding on nature of acts.
